Notes: No policy change. Regulations updated 20 Sept. No NSW public schools are currently operating without restrictions (level 1). Region specific rules are in place that range from staggering in-person teaching, mask requirements, and mask recommendations. Further lockdowns (starting from 6pm) are in place for regions with high incidence rates (Albury, Lismore, Glen Innes, Hilltops LGAs).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210920175125/https://education.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/advice-for-families

Starting 11 October stay-at-home orders are being lifted in stages across NSW, Victoria, and part of Sydney. Schools will return to face-to-face learning either through a âstaged returnâ or âfull returnâ, depending on health conditions in their area. Now in areas where 75% of the eligible population over the age of 16 are fully vaccinated, students in kindergarten, years 1 and 12 return to in-person teaching. The remaining grades will return the week beginning 25 October.     Schools in areas where stay-at-home rules had been in place for an extended period of time (continuously from August 2021) will follow a staged return to on-site learning under Level 3 plus settings from 18 October.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211018075601/https://education.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/advice-for-families  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017214229/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/oct/17/victoria-and-nsw-schools-are-reopening-amid-covid-outbreaks-what-can-be-learnt-from-overseas

No policy changes. Continuing from 16 Sept twelve regions are coming out of lockdown but other areas of AUS remain in lockdown with a stay-at-home order. Under stay-at-home there is a closure of retail businesses for all but essential businesses. The goods and services must be picked up within the local government area where you live, or within 5km of where you live but not in another area of concern.     In the twelve areas coming out of lockdown restrictions are still in place: Retail stores can reopen under the one person per 4sqm rule. Personal services such as hairdressers and nail salons can open with one person per 4sqm, capped at five clients per premises.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210920193638/https://www.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/changes-to-stay-at-home-orders-for-regional-nsw-local-government-areas    https://web.archive.org/web/20210922062403/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/affected-area

No policy changes. Continuing from 16 Sept areas of AUS remain in lockdown with a stay-at-home order. Under stay-at-home there is a closure of retail businesses for all but essential businesses. The goods and services must be picked up within the local government area where you live, or within 5km of where you live but not in another area of concern.     In the areas coming out of lockdown restrictions are still in place: Retail stores can reopen under the one person per 4sqm rule. Personal services such as hairdressers and nail salons can open with one person per 4sqm, capped at five clients per premises.     Current areas under lockdown are: Bayside, Blacktown, Burwood, Campbelltown, Canterbury-Bankstown, Cumberland, Fairfield, Georges River, Liverpool, Parramatta, Strathfield, and some suburbs of Penrith.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004184502/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/news/Pages/20211004_01.aspx    https://web.archive.org/web/20210921110657/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/changes    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004183442/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/affected-area

On 11 October 2021 NSW opened and ended lockdown as the state passed the 70% double vaccination target. Workers in these regional areas who have received one vaccination dose will be permitted to return to their workplace from October 11 and will be given a grace period until November 1 to receive their second dose. Staff who work indoors must wear face masks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211015073454/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/business/rules  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018081943/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/easing-covid-19-restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018082938/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/news/Pages/20211003_01.aspx    Currently Melbourne is still under lockdown (to end this Fri 22 Oct). Shopping is restricted to necessary goods and services (once per day, one person per household) and authorized work requires a permit.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211017235131/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-covidsafe-settings  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018082421/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/10/17/australias-melbourne-set-to-end-worlds-longest-lockdowns

Targeted regions have canceled events to comply with stay-at-home orders. New starting 20 September, those who are fully vaccinated and over 16 years old can attend an outdoor gathering in a public space of up to 5 people for exercise or outdoor recreation. Previously vaccination was not considered. Those who are not fully vaccinated can attend an outdoor gathering in a public space with 1 other person that you do not live with, or your nominated visitor ("singles bubble") for exercise or outdoor recreation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210920195542/https://www.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/restrictions-to-ease-lgas-of-concern  https://web.archive.org/web/20210920194117/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/affected-regions

On 11 October 2021 NSW opened and ended lockdown as the state passed the 70% double vaccination target. Events can resume with 75% capacity and social distancing rules.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211018081943/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/easing-covid-19-restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018082938/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/news/Pages/20211003_01.aspx  https://web.archive.org/web/20211015073454/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/business/rules    Currently Melbourne is still under lockdown (to end this Fri 22 Oct). A stay-at-home curfew is in place for metropolitan Melbourne. Between 9:00pm and 5:00am, you cannot leave your home (or the home of your intimate partner or bubble buddy) other than for essential reasons. Shopping is restricted to necessary goods and services (once per day, one person per household) and authorized work requires a permit.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211017235131/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-covidsafe-settings  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018082421/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/10/17/australias-melbourne-set-to-end-worlds-longest-lockdowns

Starting 20 September, those who live alone no longer have to register their nominated visitor ('singles bubble') with Service NSW. Although the registration is lifted, these 'nominated visitors' can only live either in a local government area of concern or Greater Sydney.    Continuing policy restrictions are in place for regions under stay-at-home order where visiting another person is not a reasonable excuse to leave your home and you must not allow a person to visit your home.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210920194523/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/affected-area

From 20 September, stay-at-home conditions are slightly relaxed. There is now no limit on the duration of outdoor exercise and recreation (previously a two-hour limit); Outdoor gatherings of up to five fully vaccinated people (not including children aged 12 and under) will be allowed in a personâs LGA or within 5km of home (previously only fully vaccinated household members could gather outdoors, or up to two fully vaccinated people from different households); Shopping, exercise and outdoor recreation can be done 5km from home or within your LGA (previously only 5km from home); Attend a small wedding (maximum 11 people) in Greater Sydney as a guest (previously only allowed in their LGA); and A personâs singleâs bubble buddy can live in Greater Sydney (previously must have resided within 5km of a personâs home). A person from a LGA of concern can also now be a buddy for someone in Greater Sydney.    From 20 September 2021 stay-at-home rules are in place for the local government area of Cowra until Tuesday 28 September 2021. The stay at home orders apply to anyone who has been in Cowra from 13 September 2021.    Continuing from early September many regions are on stay-at-home orders with exceptions for reasonable, essential excuses. Stay-at-home orders remain in place in the following local government areas â Bathurst Regional, Bourke, Brewarrina, City of Broken Hill, Central Coast, Central Darling, City of Cessnock, Dubbo Regional, Eurobodalla, Gilgandra, Goulburn Mulwarre, Kiama, City of Lake Macquarie, City of Lithgow, City of Maitland, Mid-Western Regional, Narromine, City of Newcastle, City of Orange, Port Stephens, Queanbeyan-Palerang Regional, City of Shellharbour, City of Shoalhaven, Walgett and Wingecarribee.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210920195542/https://www.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/restrictions-to-ease-lgas-of-concern  https://web.archive.org/web/20210920194523/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/affected-area

No new policies. In areas of stay-at-home orders, you must carry a face mask with you at all times when you leave your home and wear a face mask when required. In areas where stay-at-home orders are easing masks remain mandatory for all indoor public venues, including public transport, front-of-house hospitality, retail and business premises, on planes and at airports. National policy recommends wearing a surgical mask when you are in the same room as the sick person. The sick person should also wear a mask when other people are in the same room.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924160129/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/affected-area    https://web.archive.org/web/20210920193638/https://www.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/changes-to-stay-at-home-orders-for-regional-nsw-local-government-areas    https://web.archive.org/web/20210916202421/https://www.health.gov.au/news/health-alerts/novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-health-alert/how-to-protect-yourself-and-others-from-coronavirus-covid-19/physical-distancing-for-coronavirus-covid-19

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting the closure of schools.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "With the consent of His Majesty the Sultan and Yang Di-Pertuan of Brunei Darussalam, it is hereby announced that the following control measures are reinstated for two weeks with immediate effect:    ...    3. Online learning will commenced for schools, other educational institutions, tuition classes, music classes and special needs classes."    Although it is initially unclear whether this directive applies to universities, Universiti Brunei Darussalam, the country's largest university, instituted Covid-19 shutdown measures on 9th August.    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See Universiti Brunei Darussalam (UBD)'s Covid-19 update page, archived at https://archive.vn/MKajg

No significant changes since the general tightening of measures on the 9th of August, except for the suspension of most in-patient dental procedures and services.    Measures were further tightened, after the discovery of more local cases on the 8th and 9th of August.    Per the press release of 09 Aug by the Ministry of Health, written in Malay,    "ii) All officers and staff, whether government or private are required to do work-from-home. Only really needed staff are allowed to go out to work such as,    frontline workers (health sector, security sector, hospitality sector, transport sector)  daily necessities sector (food, retail business)  facilities and utilities sector (electricity, water, telecommunications)  officers at the borders and entrances to Brunei Darussalam  oil and gas and downstream sectors  development sector  agri-food and forestry sectors"    See the Ministry of Health's initial press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU  See the Ministry of Health's press release on dental procedures (dated 15th August), archived at https://archive.vn/BAxD8

No changes.    Measures were further tightened, after the discovery of more local cases on the 8th and 9th of August.    Per the press release of 09 Aug by the Ministry of Health, written in Malay,    "i) Any public gathering is not allowed. However, exceptions are allowed as follows:    A group of 15 people for funeral management (not COVID-19).  A group of 5 people for the marriage ceremony."    Additionally, "iii) Leaving the house without a significant purpose is not allowed. Only two people from one family are allowed out of the house to buy daily necessities."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU

No change.    After local transmission cases were found in Brunei on 07 Aug in over a year, public transport capacity was reduced effective from 09 Aug.    Per the press release of 08 Aug by the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications, written in Malay,    "1.3.1 Public transport operators are limited to 50 per cent seating capacity in public transport vehicles."    See the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/dkRj1

No change. The only country-specific exception to the total travel ban is the Reciprocal Green Lane with Singapore, which has resumed with effect from 12th July (https://archive.vn/Eevqo). Other foreigners can only enter Brunei under specific essential travel circumstances (see below).    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 30 Sep, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:        Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    ---    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  â¢ Essential business travel (including official travel)  â¢ Students  â¢ Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  â¢ Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/cGZuW  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf

No change. The only country-specific exception to the total travel ban is the Reciprocal Green Lane with Singapore, which has resumed with effect from 12th July (https://archive.vn/Eevqo). Other foreigners can only enter Brunei under specific essential travel circumstances (see below).    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 05 Oct, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:        Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    ---    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  â¢ Essential business travel (including official travel)  â¢ Students  â¢ Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  â¢ Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/cY1bs  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf

No changes/deviation; Brunei continues to maintain a systematic, coordinated public campaign re: COVID.    The government continues to maintain an overall website where citizens can access any information related to COVID.   https://archive.vn/PwOIW    There is also an overall site on the Ministry of Health's website pertaining to Covid-19 vaccination (the programme, FAQ, public health messaging).  https://archive.vn/5UFPG    The Ministry of Health continues to update COVID case numbers daily (especially since the recent outbreak). See, for example, 29 Sep (https://archive.vn/hSw5j) and 30 Sep (https://archive.vn/31cRW).    No updates were missing.

No change.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 30 Sep,    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Brunei?  Yes.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes.  Members of the public who need to undergo a swab test for any reason are advised to go to the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha (RIPAS) Hospital, or other health centers where testing is provided.  The testing fee for foreigners is BND $200 [sic, current cost as per Brunei's Ministry of Health is BND $50].  More information is available here.  Test results will be delivered through SMS.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/cGZuW  See the Ministry of Health press release on testing cost (22 May), archived at https://archive.vn/kU9pS

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting mandatory mask measures.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "Meanwhile, to address the concerns on the spread of Delta variant around the world, including in Brunei Darussalam, the Ministry of Health would also like to inform the public on the changes in the face mask guidelines:    1. Face masks are required be worn at all times, especially indoors or in crowded places either indoor or outdoor.  2. Face mask must cover the wearer's nose and mouth.  3. This directive is applicable to all individuals regardless of their vaccination status."    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 30 Sep,    "Face masks are mandatory at all times in all indoor and outdoor spaces."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/cGZuW

Vaccination groups: Phase 1, 2 and 3 under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy  Phase 1: Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above; students studying abroad;  and  Phase 2: teachers; childcare centre staff/childcare workers; adults at high risk or suffering from chronic diseases  and  Phase 3: individuals aged 18 years and above    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV); Moderna (elasomeran/mRNA-1273)    NOTE: The temporary halt for people getting their first doses due to an unexpected supply issue for vaccines was lifted on 23rd September, after China donated more Sinopharm vaccines to Brunei. "A total of 100,000 doses of Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine and 102,400 syringes donated by the Chinese government arrived at Brunei on Sept. 12." "Australia and Japan [have also] both pledged 100,000 doses of AstraZeneca each", with Brunei offering the AstraZeneca vaccine as the default first shot. Singapore has donated an additional 100,000 doses of Moderna vaccines (elasomeran) on 28 September, after an initial tranche of 100,000 in August.     Brunei's Phase 3 of its Vaccination Strategy, for individuals aged 18 years and above, commenced on 05 July. "[Individuals] who wish to get the COVID-19 vaccinations during Phase 3 are required to reserve a slot".    See:  The Ministry of Health's press release "Registration For The National Vaccination Program For Covid-19 For The Phase Three" (dated 01 Jul), archived at https://archive.vn/M1nb1  The Ministry of Health's press release "Registration For The National Vaccination Program For COVID-19 For The Second Phase" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/nzwGg  The Scoop's report, entitled "Phase 2 of COVID-19 vaccination starts on June 21" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/qgiQm  The Ministry of Health's press release "COVID-19 Moderna vaccine arrived in Brunei Darussalam" (dated 20 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/2onLe  Borneo Bulletin's report, entitled "Second phase of COVID-19 vaccination begins" (dated 22 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/XhM2i  The Star Online's report, entitled "Brunei: Over 76, 000 received Covid-19 vaccination as country goes 417 without local cases" (dated 28 Jun), archived at https://archive.is/7F2bK  Xinhua's report, entitled "Brunei continues COVID-19 vaccination with China's Sinopharm donations" (dated 16 Sep), archived at https://archive.vn/k5deH  The Scoop's report, entitled "MoH: Two jabs 83% effective in preventing COVID-19 infection" (dated 15 Sep), archived at https://archive.vn/5NITD  The Scoop's report, entitled "AstraZeneca is now Bruneiâs default vaccine" (dated 18 Sep), archived at https://archive.vn/SbAOq  The Ministry of Health's press release "Contribution of Moderna Vaccine from Singapore" (dated 28 Sep), archived at https://archive.vn/kgAa3

See:  The Ministry of Health's press release "Registration For The National Vaccination Program For Covid-19 For The Phase Three" (dated 01 Jul), archived at https://archive.vn/M1nb1  The Ministry of Health's press release "Registration For The National Vaccination Program For COVID-19 For The Second Phase" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/nzwGg  The Scoop's report, entitled "Phase 2 of COVID-19 vaccination starts on June 21" (dated 14 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/qgiQm  The Ministry of Health's press release "COVID-19 Moderna vaccine arrived in Brunei Darussalam" (dated 20 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/2onLe  Borneo Bulletin's report, entitled "Second phase of COVID-19 vaccination begins" (dated 22 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/XhM2i  The Star Online's report, entitled "Brunei: Over 76, 000 received Covid-19 vaccination as country goes 417 without local cases" (dated 28 Jun), archived at https://archive.is/7F2bK  Xinhua's report, entitled "Brunei continues COVID-19 vaccination with China's Sinopharm donations" (dated 16 Sep), archived at https://archive.vn/k5deH  The Scoop's report, entitled "MoH: Two jabs 83% effective in preventing COVID-19 infection" (dated 15 Sep), archived at https://archive.vn/5NITD  The Scoop's report, entitled "AstraZeneca is now Bruneiâs default vaccine" (dated 18 Sep), archived at https://archive.vn/SbAOq  The Ministry of Health's press release "Contribution of Moderna Vaccine from Singapore" (dated 28 Sep), archived at https://archive.vn/kgAa3

No change in policy since last iteration.    Additionally, under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, senior citizens of age 60 and above belong to Phase 1, alongside Bruneians studying abroad and frontliners.    The advice for elderly people to be protected via vaccinations was reiterated on 07 Aug, when Brunei first detected its first local transmission cases in over a year. "Individuals who have not yet received COVID-19 vaccination especially those at high risk such as the elderly and those with chronic diseases are advised to reserve an vaccination slot as soon as possible. Walk-ins at vaccination centres will only be allowed for senior citizens aged 60 and above or individuals with special needs."    See https://web.archive.org/web/20210111022516/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Lists/Latest%20news/NewDispForm.aspx?ID=727  See also, Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, archived on Dropbox, at https://www.dropbox.com/s/yri6djij3ieblma/BRN-202103__-MOH-VaccinationStrategyV2.pdf  See also, IMF's summary on the vaccination groups under "Brunei: Reopening of the Economy", archived at https://web.archive.org/web/20210907090853/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  See the Ministry of Health's press release dated 07 Aug, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL

This percentage includes 10,720 fully vaccinated residents between the ages of 12 â 17, and 109,012 fully vaccinated adults. 200 doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine have been administered to eligible residents as either a booster or an additional dose. 11 doses of the Moderna vaccine have been administered as an additional dose to eligible residents.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211001211621/https://guamrecovery.com/198th-covid-19-related-fatality-reported-59-hospitalized-127-of-928-test-positive-pfizer-biontech-covid-19-booster-shots-available/

According to UNESCO âglobal monitoring of school closure datasetâ schools are partially open in Indonesia since July,19,2021.   Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003221214/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse.    Schools are allowed to open with half of the number of the number of students in attendance in region designated as at level 3 community activity restrictions. However, as of Sep, 21, ten cities are still under level 4 community activity restrictions where schools are not opened. These are Aceh Tamiang, Pidie, Bangka Belitung, Padang, Banjar Baru, Balikpapan, Kutai Kartanegara, Tarakan, and Bulungan. Source: Garda World   Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003223803/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/526591/indonesia-authorities-extend-covid-19-restrictions-and-downgrade-all-level-4-localities-in-java-and-bali-through-oct-4-update-87     In Jakarta, classes held at 50% of the usual size, with the students attending on three days a week (Monday, Wednesday and Friday), while the remaining days will be used to spray classrooms with disinfectant. Students and teachers wear masks and practice social distancing at schools. Source: The Guardian   Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003222259/https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2021/aug/30/children-return-to-school-in-jakarta-as-indonesia-eases-covid-restrictions

As of Sep, 21, ten cities are under level 4 community activity restrictions. These are Aceh Tamiang, Pidie, Bangka Belitung, Padang, Banjar Baru, Balikpapan, Kutai Kartanegara, Tarakan, and Bulungan. Source: Garda World   Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003223803/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/526591/indonesia-authorities-extend-covid-19-restrictions-and-downgrade-all-level-4-localities-in-java-and-bali-through-oct-4-update-87     Under level 4, employee in non-essential industries must continue to telecommunicate. Staff from essential sector can work on site at various capacity limit; essential service and office administration workers may work on-site at 50% and 25% capacity respectively. Supermarkets can open until 21:00 at 50% capacity. Food stalls and street vendors may operate with health protocol in place; dine-in is allowed at a maximum of three customers. Restaurants and cafes are limited to takeaway services but may offer dine-in services of up to 25% capacity with only two guests per table if situated outdoors. All food establishments can operate through 20:00 daily with a maximum meal time of 30 minutes for dine-in customers. Most retail establishments and recreational facilities remain closed. Places of worship may operate at 50% capacity or with a cap of 50 people. Domestic long-distance travel restrictions remain in place. Individuals must provide a vaccination card indicating at least one dose of the COVID-19 vaccine and a negative result from a PCR test taken within 48 hours of departure for air travel. People traveling by land or sea must provide a vaccination card indicating at least one dose of the COVID-19 vaccine or a negative rapid antigen test result taken within 48 hours. Official may randomly subject some passengers to tests. All air and sea domestic travellers must register on the Health Alert Card (eHAC) mobile application before travel; official advice travellers to download the PeduliLindungi contact tracing application. Expected timeframe Sep,21 to Oct,05. Source: Garda World  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003223803/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/526591/indonesia-authorities-extend-covid-19-restrictions-and-downgrade-all-level-4-localities-in-java-and-bali-through-oct-4-update-87
No change.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210923062549/https://covid19.go.id/penanganan-kesehatan?page=4&search=

The Indonesian government has prohibited foreign visitors from transiting and traveling to Indonesian territory unless they are in possession of a valid residence permit or certain classes of visas. International travellers entering Indonesia will be required to show proof of full vaccination against COVID-19. International travellers who cannot be vaccinated due to medical conditions and children under 12 years of age are exempted from showing proof of vaccination.   Travellers are required to have a negative COVID-19 PCR test obtained within 72-hours of their departure. Travellers are required to quarantine at their own expense at a government designated hotel for eight days and are required to take two mandatory PCR tests while in hotel quarantine before proceeding to their destination. In the event of a positive test result travellers will be required to stay at quarantine for 14 to 32 days at their own expense. Source: United State embassy Indonesia.  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003232827/https://id.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/    Indonesian authorities continue to ban entry for noncitizen who have visited India in the past 14 days. International travellers must download the PeduliLindungi contact tracing application. Seven COVID-19 vaccines have been approved under âemergency use authorizationâ to be used in Indonesia: CoronaVac (Sinovac), COVID-19 Bio Farma, AstraZeneca, Sinopharm, Moderna, Comirnaty (Pfizer and BioNTech), and Sputnik-V. Source: ANTARA news  Archived link: https://archive.vn/QiQ41    Indonesia is seeking to vaccinate 208,265,720 citizens to build herd immunity against the coronavirus under its nationwide vaccination drive, which was rolled out on January 13, 2021.  Source: ANTARA news  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211004173439/https://en.antaranews.com/news/192585/over-53-million-indonesians-receive-second-covid-19-dose     As of Sep,29, 89.8 million first shots, accounting for 43.1 percent of the target, and 50.4 million second shots, or 24.2 percent of the target have been administered. Source: ANTARA news  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211004174731/https://en.antaranews.com/news/191693/indonesians-prepare-to-learn-to-live-with-covid-19  Third booster dose have been administered to health workers, and as of October, 4; the number of health workers received a third dose was 962,619. He assured that the government will continue to administer vaccines, including to the general public, especially to those 12 years and over, pregnant women, and elderly people. During "Silver Week", all public schools in Tokyo Metropolitan Area from September 20 to 26 will be temporarily closed to in-person learning. Students are expected to return on Sep 27.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910022721/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013252101000.html (Silver Week suspension in Tokyo)

The a week suspension of in-person learning for students in the Metropolitan Tokyo area has ended and all classes have resumed inline with other prefectures across Japan.  The government of Japan has decided all emergency and priority measures will be lighted for all prefectures on October 1. Included, all schools across Japan currently stagger attendance by grades or classes will resume full capacity in-person learning on October 1. Continued focus on sanization, contact tracing within schools, and restrictions on club activities or school excursions will remain. Individual schools also have the jurisdiction to temporarily close due to infection outbreaks on a case-by-case basis.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210910022721/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210909/k10013252101000.html (Silver Week)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003032546/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013280271000.html (Resumption of school)

On October 1, Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and will undergo a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    Many prefectures and school districts have been staggering class attendance but will begin in-person learning at full capacity due to measures being lifted. Schools are to continue undergoing stringent sanitation and infection prevention measures, restricting club activities with high risk of infection and suspension of all school excursions. Students with illness symptoms are not to attend schools. Individual schools may also have the jurisdiction to close due to in-school outbreaks on a school-by-school basis.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190427/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003191110/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211001/k10013285601000.html (resumption of classes)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190946/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211001/k10013286091000.html (resumption of classes)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190640/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/638/20211001.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190745/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928taisyohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa)

No change to previous policy as Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and will undergo a precautionary period for one month. No change to previous policy as Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and continues undergoing a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    Schools have all resumed in-person learning at full capacity due to measures being lifted. Schools are to continue undergoing stringent sanitation and infection prevention measures, restricting club activities with high risk of infection and suspension of all school excursions. Increased ventilation measures and distribution of antigen test kits will also continue to be conducted. Students with illness symptoms are not to attend schools. Individual schools may also have the jurisdiction to close due to in-school outbreaks on a school-by-school basis.    There are recent examples of individual school closures as a result of outbreaks in Agano City, Niigata and Fukui City, Fukui.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017023958/https://www.niikei.jp/227863/ (Agano City)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017024018/https://www.fukui-tv.co.jp/?post_type=fukui_news&p=143499 (Fukui City)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017023524/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200105/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1007taishohousin.pdf (Okinawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200827/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928eigo.pdf (Okinawa)

No change to previous policy. As of September 13, all emergency and priority measures will continue until September 30.  State of emergency measures apply to: Hokkaido, Gifu, Aichi, Mie, Shiga, Hiroshima, Okinawa, Tokyo, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Osaka, Ibaraki, Tochigi, Gunma, Shizuoka, Kyoto, Hyogo, Fukuoka.  Priority measures apply to: Ishikawa, Fukushima, Kumamoto, Kagawa, Kagoshima, Miyazaki, Miyagi, Okayama.    Okinawa will continue to close public facilities effective until Sep 30.  For prefectures under emergency orders: nightclubs, cabarets, karaoke parlors and bars not licensed as a restaurant must close. Restaurants may service customers provided restaurants follow shorten business hours from 5am to 8pm. All other businesses and events should also operate between 5am to 8pm.  For prefectures under priority measures: Alcohol restrictions have been lifted allowing alcohol to be served until 7:30pm. Local governments also request all businesses operate between 5am to 9pm with the exception of restaurants which should operate between 5am to 8pm. Meeting halls, theatres, recreational facilities, places of tourism or leisure all must comply within these guidelines for shorten business hours.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924203224/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013547/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/484/20210909/20210909.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924203712/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0923taisyohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918004444/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0909eigo.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910015844/https://www.pref.kumamoto.jp/soshiki/30/104632.html

On October 1, Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and will undergo a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    All businesses including bars and nightclubs are able to reopen provided businesses serving alcohol receives a certificate of inspection for infection control by the Ministry of Health, however karaoke equipment is requested not to be used. During the precautionary period, all businesses are requested to operate at shortened business hours between 5:00AM to 9:00PM with alcohol permitted to being served 11:00AM to 8:00PM (in Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, and Okinawa). In Tochigi, alcohol may be served until 7:30PM; and in Okinawa, acohol may be served until 7:00PM.  Businesses are asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190427/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193347/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013281591000.html (restrictions in Kanto region)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193702/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013281561000.html (restrictioins in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190640/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/638/20211001.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190745/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928taisyohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa)

Businesses are asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017023524/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193347/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013281591000.html (restrictions in Kanto region)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193702/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013281561000.html (restrictions in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200105/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1007taishohousin.pdf (Okinawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200827/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928eigo.pdf (Okinawa)

On Oct 15, requests for shorten business hours at restaurants and bars have been lifted for the following prefectures: Hiroshima, Gifu, and Fukuoka.  Remote working whenever possible continues to be encouraged by the federal government.    For all other prefectures, businesses are requested to operate at shortened business hours between 5:00AM to 9:00PM with alcohol permitted to being served 11:00AM to 8:00PM (in Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, and Okinawa). In Tochigi, alcohol may be served until 7:30PM; and in Okinawa, acohol may be served until 7:00PM. Businesses have also been asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017023524/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017222328/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211015/k10013308261000.html (Hiroshima, Gifu, Fukuoka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193347/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013281591000.html (restrictions in Kanto region)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193702/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013281561000.html (restrictions in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200105/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1007taishohousin.pdf (Okinawa)

No change to previous policy. As of September 13, all emergency and priority measures will continue until September 30.  State of emergency measures apply to: Hokkaido, Gifu, Aichi, Mie, Shiga, Hiroshima, Okinawa, Tokyo, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Osaka, Ibaraki, Tochigi, Gunma, Shizuoka, Kyoto, Hyogo, Fukuoka.  Priority measures apply to: Ishikawa, Fukushima, Kumamoto, Kagawa, Kagoshima, Miyazaki, Miyagi, Okayama.    Okinawa will continue their extended state of emergency until September 30, where events with a maximum of 1,000 people at 50% venue capacity may proceed to be held. Events with no spectators, however, are being recommended.  All other prefectures under emergency orders, events with a maximum of 5,000 people at a 50% venue capacity may proceed to be held.    For other prefectures under priority or no measures, if the gathering does not require loud cheering, the event may proceed at 100% facility capacity for a maximum of 5,000 people or less. For gatherings with loud cheering, the event may proceed at 50% facility capacity for a maximum of 5,000 people or less. All events must end at 9pm in prefectures with priority measures.  Local governments continue to encourage residents to stay home and to avoid going to crowded places or engaging in high risk activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924203224/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013547/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/484/20210909/20210909.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924203712/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0923taisyohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918004444/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0909eigo.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910015844/https://www.pref.kumamoto.jp/soshiki/30/104632.html

On October 1, Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and will undergo a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    During the precautionary period, all events are asked to be completed by 9:00PM. For events involving loud events, capacity is limited to 50% of the venue capacity and not exceed an upper limit of 10,000 people. For events with no loud voices, 100% of the venue capacity may be used but not exceed an upper limit of 5,000 people. In Okinawa, loud events are limited to 50% venue capacity and must not exceed 5,000 people.  Businesses are asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM. Drinking gatherings at bars are asked to to be limited to 4 people per group.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190427/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193347/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013281591000.html (restrictions in Kanto region)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193702/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013281561000.html (restrictioins in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190640/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/638/20211001.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190745/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928taisyohoshin_1.pdf (Okinawa)

No change to previous policy. All public transportation continues to remain in operation.  Tokyo Metro has posted alternative commuter office hours during the Tokyo state of emergency. In addition, public information on cases among employees are updated as of Sep 17. For the week of September 20-26 ("Silver Week," a week that has consists of 2 national holidays on weekdays), the government of Japan is requesting citizens to avoid non-essential movement in an effort to lift the country's state of emergencies.  Okinawa continues to ask all residents to stop holding events and travelling to remote islands and non-essential movement to be reduce by 50%.  The Government of Japan continues to encourage residents to stay home and avoid areas or activities of high risk for infection.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210918000712/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210912/k10013255591000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924203224/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910013547/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/484/20210909/20210909.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924203712/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0923taisyohoshin.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918004444/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0909eigo.pdf

Border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism and other short-term purposes remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended.  For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by   variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Sep 17).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924205040/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210918050209/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C125.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924205024/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/

Border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism and other short-term purposes remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended.  For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Sep 27).  To be eligible for a shortened quarantine period, Japan has so far designated only Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna as valid certificates of vaccination. All certificates must be issued by the public institution from government or country of origin, and must be written in either Japanese or English containing the following information: name, date of birth, vaccine name or manufacturer, vaccination date, dose. In addition, 14-days or more must have passed from the second dose date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003202905/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003203427/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C127.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003203141/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003203912/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/covid19/certificate_to_Japan.html

For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Sep 27).  To be eligible for a shortened quarantine period, Japan has so far designated only Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna as valid certificates of vaccination. All certificates must be issued by the public institution from government or country of origin, and must be written in either Japanese or English containing the following information: name, date of birth, vaccine name or manufacturer, vaccination date, dose. In addition, 14-days or more must have passed from the second dose date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008204034/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008204749/https://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/files/100238774.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008204828/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C127.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008204046/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003203912/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/covid19/certificate_to_Japan.html

Border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism and other short-term purposes remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended.  For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Sep 27).  To be eligible for a shortened quarantine period, Japan has so far designated only Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna as valid certificates of vaccination. All certificates must be issued by the public institution from government or country of origin, and must be written in either Japanese or English containing the following information: name, date of birth, vaccine name or manufacturer, vaccination date, dose. In addition, 14-days or more must have passed from the second dose date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017184357/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008204749/https://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/files/100238774.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017184616/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C129.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017184818/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/covid19/certificate_to_Japan.html

No change to previous policy. New subsidy application deadlines for July-Nov 2021 have been set for December 31, 2021 (support document revised as of Sep 9).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924205751/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910192507/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

No change to previous policy. New debt relief application deadlines for July-Nov 2021 have been set for December 31, 2021 (support document revised as of Sep 9).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924205751/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210910192507/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924205939/https://corona.go.jp/action

No change to previous policy.  800,000 antigen test kits have been distributed to kindergartens, elementary, and middle schools for surveillance purposes for the start of the fall semester.  Antigen tests are limitedly available to eligible cluster cases when fast results are requested for a large number of people. Typically due to potential inaccuracies, negative antigen tests are re-tested via PCR.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210827194425/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210827/k10013227701000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924213307/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924213329/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html

No change to previous policy.  Antigen tests are limitedly available to eligible cluster cases when fast results are requested for a large number of people. Typically due to potential inaccuracies, negative antigen tests are re-tested via PCR.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    PCR tests, antigen tests, and antibody tests may be requested for asymptomatic individuals for the purposes of travel will however, be charged by laboratory facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211003204849/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924213329/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003205333/https://jp.usembassy.gov/services/pcr-testing-facilities-in-japan/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003205304/https://hiro-clinic.jp/

PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    PCR tests, antigen tests, and antibody tests may be requested for asymptomatic individuals for the purposes of travel will however, be charged by laboratory facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (rapid antigent testing in schools)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205543/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205549/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205625/https://jp.usembassy.gov/services/pcr-testing-facilities-in-japan/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003205304/https://hiro-clinic.jp/

On Oct 15, as a result of the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare approving the sale of rapid antigen testing for the general public nationwide, rapid antigen tests begin being sold in pharmacies. All purchasers are to sign a consent form with a pharmacist explaining the technology and in the case of a positive test, all individuals must seek medical attention from appropriate authorities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017225754/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211015/k10013309151000.html

In Osaka due to current high rates of infection, it may take an upwards of 4 days to be contacted by designated contact tracers. There continues to be a reduction in ability to conduct full close contact tracing in Tokyo and Saitama due to the high number of infections. Close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205930/https://www.kobe-np.co.jp/news/tanba/202109/0014706179.shtml (evidence of contact tracing in Kobe)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924214016/https://www.hokkoku.co.jp/articles/tym/534241 (evidence of contact tracing in Toyama)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924214131/https://www.sanin-chuo.co.jp/articles/-/98731 (evidence of contact tracing in Tottori)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924213853/https://www.sankeibiz.jp/macro/news/210907/mca2109070604003-n1.htm (Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210906201209/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210901/k10013237791000.html (Saitama)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823030440/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20210821-OYT1T50023/ (Tokyo & Saitama)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210814022625/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210814/k10013201711000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210924214251/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.html (Government testing information)

No change to previous policy.  There continues to be a reduction in ability to conduct full close contact tracing in Tokyo and Saitama due to the number of infections and the resources required. Close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008210133/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/local/osaka/news/20211004-OYTNT50138/ (contact tracing in Hikata, Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008210247/https://www.fnn.jp/articles/-/249325 (contact tracing in Fujinomiya, Shizuoka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008212109/https://news.line.me/articles/oa-jolf/0d358cd69958 (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823030440/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20210821-OYT1T50023/ (Tokyo & Saitama)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008210026/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.html

No change to previous policy.  There is no evidence limitations for close contact tracing has fully resumed in Tokyo and Saitama. For many wards in Tokyo, close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities and also have shifted focus in making sure those severely ill are properly traced.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017195316/https://www.m3.com/news/open/iryoishin/973681 (Tokyo wards)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017201311/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/lnews/okinawa/20211014/5090015934.html (evidence of contact tracing in Okinawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017201411/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/local/osaka/news/20211004-OYTNT50138/ (evidence of Hirakata, Osaka preparing for more streamlined contact tracing efforts in the event of a new wave)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823030440/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20210821-OYT1T50023/ (Tokyo & Saitama)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017201307/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.html

No change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is widely spread and continues to be recommended by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924214431/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00094.html

On September 17, in order to promote uptake of vaccination in individuals 39 years old and younger, Minato ward in Tokyo will be operating a weekend midnight vaccination clinic every Friday. This late-night operating clinic will allow those in the workforce who are worried about taking time off work due to potential next day side effects to be inoculated.    https://archive.vn/FHmXG

In Shinjuku Ward, the number of mass inoculation venues, which was 17 as of July, has been reduced to 10 due to the decrease in supply. To accomodate for the higher population of young people (18-39 year olds) in certain areas within Tokyo, the Japanese government will be redirecting supply from other locales to necessary wards in Tokyo.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210924175631/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210922/k10013272411000.html

As of September 26, at large scale vaccination sites in Tokyo and Osaka, there is surplus of vacant vaccination appointments available in the coming few weekdays for a total of 8100 spots still available for booking. The government is urging all residents above 18 years old to get vaccinated.  Priority vaccinations continue to be administered for junior high school students, high school students, and their families with children who are about to enter examination period. Priority vaccinations are also occurring for pregnant women and their families.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211002175553/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210925/k10013275931000.html (examinee vaccinations)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211002175629/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210925/k10013276631000.html (pregnancy vaccinations)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211002180024/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210927/k10013279131000.html (surplus appointments)

Due to the continued surplus in vacant slots at mass vaccination sites in Tokyo and Osaka, the Japanese government has lifted restrictions for young people priority bookings. All residents age 16+ are able to begin booking at mass vaccination sites on September 30 for slots beginning October 4. For junior and high school students age 12+, reservations will begin October 1 for slots starting October 4.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211002181039/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013283021000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211002181528/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html

In Osaka, an announcement was made that all Osakan mass vaccination sites will begin administering walk-in vaccinations (no reservations required) for resident age 16+ beginning October 4.    As of Oct 1, 70.4% of the total population in Japan (including those under the eligible age for vaccination) have received their first dose, with 59.8% of the total population having received both doses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211002182119/https://osaka-mvc.com/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211002182806/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/

On October 4, walk-in (no reservation) vaccinations begin for residents 16 years old and up at mass vaccination venues in Osaka Prefecture.  On October 4, Tokyo begins vaccinating residents 12 years old and up for those who have reserved slots at mass vaccination sites in Tokyo Metropolitan Area.    Third dose vaccinations is being planned to begin in December 2021.  As of Oct 8, 72.8% of the total population in Japan (including those under the eligible age for vaccination) have received their first dose, with 63.1% of the total population having received both doses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008213231/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008213225/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211006/k10013294641000.html (Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008213929/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008213628/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211004/k10013290701000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008213451/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291661000.html (third doses)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211002182806/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/

In Vientiane, employees, enterprises, international organizations to stop working in offices from Sept 20-30 except for military, police, firefighters, health care workers, officials and volunteers working in electricity, water, community services, prevention, control and treatment of infected cases.  Karaoke bars, entertainment venues and casinos must close during this time. Spas, barber shops, malls, restaurants, bars are prohibited from opening. Factories will be closed. All indoor sports centers will also shut down and people are prohibited to exercise outdoors at public places.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003013308/https:/www.covid19.gov.la/index.php?r=site%2Fdetail&id=942  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003205238/https:/www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/526181/laos-authorities-enact-lockdown-measures-in-vientiane-capital-through-sept-30-due-to-covid-19-update-6

Police-military checkpoints will inspect and collect information and documentation. Individuals from other provinces with community transmission are prohibited from traveling to Vientaine capital. On July 30, 2020, Burmese authorities updated implemented enhanced screening and quarantine measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19, to include the following:  All foreign nationals, including U.S. citizens, must first self-quarantine in their countries of origin for seven days, quarantine in a government facility or designated hotel upon arriving for another 14 days, and then self-quarantine at home for seven days.  These guidelines are subject to change without notice.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211011024056/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/     the Ministry of Health will lift temporary ban on residents of the Republic of India and the Peopleâs Republic of Bangladesh and travelers who had visited the Republic of India and the Peopleâs Republic of Bangladesh during the last 14 days, from visiting Myanmar. The measure will take effect starting from 24th September 2021, 2359 hours MST.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211011031806/https://www.mohs.gov.mm/page/17500

The Social Security Board, under the Ministry of Labor, Immigration and Population, will pay 40 percent of the salary to insured workers, as a family assistance fund, in accordance with the Social Security Law.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211011032412/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Household support. In-kind and cash transfers to the most vulnerable population (MMK 404billion)through Apr-Sep and 4 round cash transfer (MMK 164 billion) in Nov-Dec;   exemptions and subsidies of household electricity charges starting July 2020 and extended to March 2021  The government has announced that it would guarantee 50 percent of new loans made by private banks to enterprises which are not beneficiaries of the government COVID fund.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211011032412/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#N
The campaign is ongoing    https://web.archive.org/web/20211005090945/https://doph.maps.arcgis.com/apps/dashboards/f8fb4ccc3d2d42c7ab0590dbb3fc26b8

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Burma?  If so, are test results reliably available with 72 hours? â YES   https://web.archive.org/web/20211011024056/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

We are identifying those who have been in close contact with the patient for 2 days before the onset of symptoms and within 14 days after the onset of symptoms, based on the recommendations of the World Health Organization (WHOID).    The laboratory confirmed patients have close contact with his family and lived in their accommodation places, People who worked together Close contacts Strict home quarantine is being monitored for those who travel together during the trip. The participation of all members of the public, including family members, is especially needed in such monitoring.    The Ministry of Health and Sports is announcing the visit to public places within 2 days before the onset of symptoms and 14 days after the onset of the symptoms of laboratory confirmation patients, and urges the public who have been in contact with these patients to contact the nearest administration and health department as soon as possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211009083727/https://mohs.gov.mm/page/8509
A mask must be worn at all times when outside the home.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211011024056/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

THE Ministry of Health conducts vaccination programmes in respective regions/states for target populations. Starting 26 July 2021, the ministry used Sinopharm and Sinovac vaccines donated by China and purchased from China to vaccinate the public for the first injection. For the second dose, the ministry distributed the vaccines via land or with the help of Tatmadaw (Air) and MAI to the remote areas starting 21 August 2021.    The vaccines were allocated to Mon, Kayin, Ayeyawady, Bago, Taninthayi, Shan, Magway, Sagaing, Mandalay, Nay Pyi Taw, Kachin and Rakhine until 25 August 2021.    These vaccines were also used to vaccinate the factory workers in Yangon, Mandalay, Bago and Ayeyawady regions. â MNA    https://web.archive.org/web/20211011034946/https://www.mdn.gov.mm/index.php/en/covid-19-vaccines-distributed-nationwide-second-injections

No change, schools still closed till 3 October 2021. When tertiary education institutions open, students are required to be fully vaccinated prior to return.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210915085132/https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/schools-in-several-malaysian-states-to-reopen-on-oct-3-at-50-per-cent-capacity

Schools are reopning in accordance with the national recovery plan but in various regions they have not moved from Stage 2 which schools are required to close.    All educational institutions are closed  All learning activities are to be conducted virtually  Only exam classes can return to school    https://web.archive.org/web/20211018174352/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/kedah/dashboard-en.html

Public sector limited to 60% employee attendance at offices subject to the Chief Secretary to the Governmentâs directive  Private sector limited to 80% employee attendance capacity, for business sectors allowed to operate  Agricultural and commodities sector may operate at full capacity    https://web.archive.org/web/20211018174352/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/kedah/dashboard-en.html

Live performances/events are not allowed  Only streaming of recordings and live streaming are allowed  Fully Vaccinated Individuals  Allowed to go to live performances/events, cinemas, art exhibitions, museums, indoor buskings and hotel lounges    https://web.archive.org/web/20211018170931/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/johor/index-en.html
All social activities and visitations are not allowed    https://web.archive.org/web/20211018174352/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/kedah/dashboard-en.html

No travelling between districts / states / country  Fully Vaccinated Individuals  Travelling to districts / states / country and tourism bubble areas is allowed  Vehicles may carry passengers at full capacity  Citizens and non-citizens who have a residence in Malaysia and arrived from abroad, may have their compulsory quarantine at home    https://web.archive.org/web/20211018174352/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/kedah/dashboard-en.html
Restrictions are in place in regions which are still in Phase 2    https://web.archive.org/web/20211018175057/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/perak/index-en.html

No changes policy changes. Auckland remains at Alert Level 3. At Alert Level 3, tamariki (children) and young people should learn from home.  The rest of New Zealand, including Upper Hauraki, is at Alert Level 2. These settings will be reviewed on Monday 4 October.    Archived link:   https://web.archive.org/web/20211003125504/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-levels-and-updates/current-alert-level/

Parts of Waikato (reviewed 14/10)    The rest of New Zealand is in Level 2.    For level 3 children and young people should learn from home. Early learning centres can open to provide childcare for children whose parents need to go into work. Play centres and playgroups must close.
